awd_abstract_narration:
The mathematical concept of a four-dimensional object allows a more comprehensive study of three-dimensional objects that exist in our physical world by considering its points (encoded as three space coordinates) together with any other relevant quantity, for example its temperature, pressure, or electric conductivity. This simultaneous treatment of space coordinates and other pointwise parameters is both essential and ubiquitous in modern science, from spacetimes in Einstein's theory of General Relativity and D-branes in Particle Physics, to mathematical models used in medical imaging and diagnosis, industrial robotics, urban traffic flows, financial markets, and wireless communications, among many others. The main goal of this project is to advance the geometric understanding of four-dimensional objects as abstract mathematical entities, an approach that is general enough to allow applications to any field that makes use of four-dimensional models. In particular, this project will analyze how rigid or malleable certain four-dimensional shapes are, how that changes under certain natural curvature assumptions, and how to efficiently detect these curvature properties. A defining characteristic of the research to be conducted is the use of cutting-edge techniques recently developed in areas of mathematics not traditionally associated with geometry, bringing new perspectives to a classical subject, in a disruptive attempt to solve some of its most important open questions. This project will also partially support the CUNY Geometric Analysis seminar, and its educational mission in the CUNY graduate program, through the communication of latest research advances in the field; as well as several public outreach activities at CUNY Lehman College, a Hispanic Serving Institution in the Bronx borough of New York City.
 
In more technical terms, this project will pursue various applications of the emerging fields of Convex Algebraic Geometry and Semidefinite Programming to Geometric Analysis and Riemannian Geometry, for instance through the study of semialgebraic sets of curvature operators of four-manifolds with sectional curvature bounds as spectrahedral shadows and limits of spectrahedra. This real algebro-geometric viewpoint on curvature operators of four-manifolds is expected to have several global consequences in the form of explicit algebraic (polynomial) characterizations of sectional curvature bounds, rank rigidity results, and optimization of curvature estimates. Furthermore, the project seeks to detect new topological obstructions to positive curvature in four-manifolds using the aforementioned techniques and trisections of their fundamental groups. Other topics covered include four-dimensional Einstein manifolds, Ricci solitons, and Ricci flow. Most of the research will be conducted in collaboration with doctoral students, early-career mathematicians, and other researchers, partially supporting the training of new specialists in the field.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
Mathematical models of three-dimensional objects generally incorporate data associated to each point regarding, for instance, temperature, light intensity, CO2 concentration, or structural stress. Such models are widely used to better understand and predict the behavior of objects of all scales, from molecules to human organs, from bridges and airplanes to entire galaxies, that already surround us or that we are designing on a computer before a prototype is even built. Higher-dimensional differential geometry naturally arises in this context, following the principle that treating all the coordinates of a point (spatial or otherwise) equally is often advantageous to unveil global geometric properties. Moreover, the conclusions obtained from studying such abstract multidimensional geometries then simultaneously apply to the myriad of real-world models that fit this language. The research efforts that were made possible by this NSF project have advanced our abstract geometric understanding of four-dimensional smooth objects, using various tools that are not traditionally used in Geometric Analysis. This NSF project also supported community outreach activities that improved mathematical literacy and appreciation, and the successful training of doctoral students that joined both the academic and non-academic U.S. workforce.


Intellectual Merit. The key research outcomes of this NSF project are new discoveries of how curvature and shape of smooth four-dimensional manifolds constrain each other and determine their flexibility or rigidity under certain deformations. Specifically, we proved new restrictions on the topology (as measured by the intersection form, signature, and Euler characteristic) of a four-dimensional manifold with positively or negatively pinched sectional curvature, for the full range of possible pinching constants. These bounds refine earlier topological finiteness results in the realm of closed simply-connected four-manifolds, and provide new symmetry-free evidence towards a negative answer to the Hopf Question on the existence of metrics with positive curvature on the product of 2-spheres. We exhibited new examples of four-dimensional manifolds that are area-extremal for positive scalar curvature, in the sense that any deformation that further increases scalar curvature must also shrink some area. Furthermore, we found explicit examples that demonstrate how redistributing the curvature of some four-dimensional manifolds according to a widely used heat-type evolution equation (Ricci flow) may not preserve sectional curvature positivity, even on a sphere. All of the above results exploit a unique characterization of sectional curvature bounds in dimension four, known as the Finsler-Thorpe trick, which is a striking application of tools from Convex Algebraic Geometry and Optimization Theory to Geometric Analysis. We began exploring to what extent such unique characterizations exist in dimensions above four, creating a roadmap to investigate similar questions in higher dimensions. We also showed that highly symmetric spaces of any dimension can be distinguished from one another just from their frequencies of vibration (Laplace eigenvalues), provided explicit formulas for the fundamental tone (first nonzero Laplace eigenvalue) of any homogeneous metric on a compact rank one symmetric space, and for all Laplace eigenvalues on distance spheres in rank one symmetric spaces.


Broader Impacts. This NSF project provided multiple training and professional development opportunities to students and early career mathematicians. Namely, it sponsored summer research assistantships for 3 doctoral students, several short research visits by postdoctoral scholars, and participation in scientific events. The weekly meetings of the CUNY Geometric Analysis Seminar were also supported by this NSF project, promoting the frequent exchange of ideas and discussions about the latest mathematical discoveries, new scientific collaborations, and hybrid networking opportunities for researchers in Geometric Analysis. Invited speakers at this seminar represented the rich diversity of mathematicians working in Geometric Analysis at all career stages. Community outreach activities were carried out throughout the duration of the project in the Bronx borough of New York City, where Lehman College is located, aimed at improving mathematical literacy and appreciation, as well as communicating research findings of this project to the general public.
